p: The stable DPPH free radical has been widely approved as a tool for the free radical-scavenging activity assessment in antioxidants (Nagai et al., 2003). In the DPPH test, the antioxidants managed to reduce the stable DPPH radical to yellow-colored diphenylpricryhydrazine. The effects of antioxidants on DPPH radical scavenging are attributed to their hydrogen-donating ability (Ye et al., 2013). In this study, an in vitro examination of the free radical scavenging activity of the essential oils is presented. The essential oils showed the highest reduction ability with an IC50 of 49.2 μg/m1. BHT and ascorbic acid were employed as positive controls that exhibited antioxidant activity, with IC50 values of 28.7 μg/m1 and 87.3 μg/m1, respectively.
